bioghist.p: In 1793 Philadelphia was swept by an epidemic of yellow fever. A Board of Health, with Dr. Benjamin Rush as a member, was created to counter the plague and monitor sanitary conditions within the city. The Board of Health employed inspectors to monitor and eliminate potential health hazards. Beginning in 1818, Board of Health members were elected by the City Council and the Commissioners of the Districts and Townships. By 1855, the Board was clearly designated a branch of the City Government.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of fifteen photocopied pages of minutes of the Philadelphia Board of Health from 1795-1796. The minutes include reports from committees and a list of inspectors for the city, Northern Liberties, and Southwark. There are three pages of index.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
